title: 107_hr4513
content: The Act may be cited as the "Social Security Number Protection Act of 2002". The Congress finds that the sale or purchase of Social Security numbers contributes to illegal activities like fraud and identity theft, posing risks to individual privacy. Social Security numbers, required for various purposes by the Federal Government, have inadvertently become tools for facilitating crime and invasions of privacy. The sale of Social Security numbers can lead to fraud and privacy invasions. The numbers, required by the Federal Government, have become tools for criminal activities. It is necessary for the Government to take action to prevent abuse of this system. Social Security numbers do not convey any meaningful information or public concern. The sale of Social Security numbers should be restricted to prevent harm to individuals. Congress should enact legislation to protect against unlawful conduct and deceptive practices related to the sale and purchase of these numbers. The curr_chunk is a section titled "SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS." In this Act, the term "Commission" refers to the Federal Trade Commission, while "person" includes individuals, partnerships, corporations, and other entities. The term "sale" involves exchanging a Social Security number for something of value, excluding government benefit applications. "Purchase" is providing something of value for a Social Security number, excluding data matching programs. The Computer Matching and Privacy Protection Act defines terms like "purchase" as exchanging value for a Social Security number, excluding government benefit applications, and "Social Security number" as defined in the Social Security Act. "State" refers to any state or territory of the United States. SEC. 4. REGULATION OF THE SALE AND PURCHASE OF SOCIAL SECURITY NUMBERS AND SOCIAL SECURITY ACCOUNT NUMBERS. Regulations will be promulgated by the Commission to restrict the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers and account numbers, ensuring they are not sold in violation of regulations. Restrictions imposed will be no broader than necessary to prevent unfair or deceptive practices. The Commission will impose restrictions on the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers to prevent fraud and harm to individuals. Exceptions will be made for law enforcement purposes. The regulations will include exceptions for the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers for law enforcement, public health, emergency situations, and research purposes with strict conditions. The regulations for the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers for research purposes require assurances that the numbers will not be used to harass, target, or publicly reveal information about individuals, will not be used to make decisions affecting individuals' rights, benefits, or privileges, and that appropriate safeguards are in place to protect privacy and confidentiality. The Commission shall promulgate regulations within 1 year of enactment, with effective dates 30 days after publication in the Federal Register. The regulations under section 553 of title 5, United States Code will take effect 30 days after publication in the Federal Register. Violations of these regulations will be treated as violations of the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The Commission will enforce these regulations with the same powers and duties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The regulations under section 553 of title 5, United States Code will take effect 30 days after publication in the Federal Register. Violations will be treated as violations of the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Commission will enforce these regulations with the same powers and duties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Any person who violates the regulations shall be subject to penalties and entitled to privileges and immunities provided in the Act. Nothing in the Act shall limit the Commission's authority under any other law. States can take civil actions if their residents are affected by violations of the regulations. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in federal court to enjoin, enforce compliance, obtain damages, or seek other relief for residents affected by violations of FTC regulations. Prior notice must be given before filing the action. The State attorney general can file a civil action in federal court to seek relief for violations of FTC regulations, with prior notice required before filing the action. Upon receiving notice, the Commission and the Attorney General have the right to move to stay the action pending the final disposition of a pending Federal matter. The Commission and the Attorney General have the right to intervene and be heard in actions related to violations of the Act or regulations. During pending criminal proceedings, no State can bring an action against a defendant named in the criminal or civil action. During pending criminal proceedings, no State can bring an action against a defendant named in the criminal or civil action for any violation alleged in that proceeding. Additionally, for civil actions, state attorneys general can still conduct investigations and compel witnesses or evidence. The venue for such actions can be any district court in the United States meeting applicable requirements. Any action under this section can be brought in any district court of the United States that meets venue requirements. Process can be served in any district where the defendant is located.
